content: it's done
hey guys welcome back to Blackmagic craft it is time to wrap up this Tudor
house build series this is part 4 in the build and if you missed the first three
episodes go back check them out to show you how to build it how to do the stucco
how to do the shingles and today I'm gonna show you how I finished it how I
painted it one of the reasons that I broke this series up in two different
episodes because usually when I build something and do it start to finish in
one video I start running out of time at some point and it's always the paint job
that suffers I've built a lot of really great things that then get a pretty
mediocre or even bad paint job because I rush it at the end this time I didn't
have to worry about that I could actually focus and do a good job
painting this house that I'd spent so much time building and I think it's
probably the best piece of terrain I've ever painted I'm not a phenomenal
painter but I'm getting pretty decent at it and I have no complaints about how it
turned out it looks really good so today I'm gonna show you how I did what how I
did it what I did it's not just gonna be paint though there's also some cool
finishing details like some weathering stuff some moss and the most fun thing I
think is the glass in the windows so that's pretty neat yeah let's paint the
house before painting this piece I applied my
black magic base coat this is just a mixture of matte Mod Podge and black
paint it serves a few purposes the main reason I do it is that it adds a lot of
strength to the little foam parts especially on areas like the roof made
up of many tiny fragile pieces of foam it makes things like the shingles far
stronger and sturdier and it helps bond them all together when I make this I mix
the black paint right into the Mod Podge to help me see where I've covered and to
kill two birds with one stone by getting my black undercoating done at the same
time it wasn't necessary to cover the grout that I used for the stucco with
the Mod Podge as it was already very hard and secure but it was just easier
to cover the whole thing and I liked having everything blacked out to give
the build a nice cohesive non-distracting look before starting the
color the majority of this house is wood so that's where I started in my painting
efforts I've discussed this in several different videos but I have a particular
way I like doing old weathered wood the trick is to not start with a dark brown
but instead use a light golden brown that is pretty diluted with water this
appears quite drastic when first applied but when it dries the black undercoat
shows through and darkens the color this color will be greatly toned down in the
later steps as well I actually did two thin coats of the golden brown before
moving on to the next color I'm not the type to get one part of a model painted
start to finish at a time I prefer to block out all the main colors first and
then move on to the layering steps for this reason I next switched over to
painting out the brickwork I painted out all the bricks with a medium gray this
gray was a very neutral black white grey without much undertone of color often I
prefer using a tan or brown undertone gray for bricks but I knew I wanted to
do the stucco with a tan I wanted a strong distinction between
the colors so I opted for a neutral gray next I blocked out all the stucco using
a light tan or kind of khaki color this was probably the most time-consuming
part of the paint job as I had to cut in all the corners and it took a few coats
to get a nice opaque color for some added visual interest I decided to go in
with a few different contrasting colors and paint a handful of the bricks
this looks really comical at this stage but after the dry brushing in the wash
is the contrast is subdued and it creates a really interesting look check
out my video that focuses on brick painting techniques if you want to get
some more guidance I used a gun metal metallic to paint out
all the small little metal details on this build which wasn't really much just
like the door hinges the door knocker and the chimney pipes the next part of
the wood painting was to do a dry brushing of a light tan adding this
element makes the details of the wood grain really pop but it also gives the
wood a really worn and weathered appearance I found that this combination
of golden brown undercoat can dry brushing and later a black wash really
makes the most believable looking aged wood
the second step in painting the stucco
took some patience and went over everything with a lighter shade of tan
but was careful to only paint the higher flat surfaces leaving the darker color
in the recesses because each section of stucco was framed by wood I had to be
really careful and do this in a tidy and detailed fashion at this point the
building still looks really high contrast and kind of ridiculous it's at
this point the allstar of the paint job steps in the black wash for this I used
my homemade black wash recipe I'll put a link up in the corner of the screen to a
video where I walk you through the process and recipe for making this wash
I think this step can be intimidating for a lot of new painters but once
you've done it a few times you learn to just trust the wash be liberal with your
application go over everything let it do its work and remember it will dry
looking a lot better than it looks when it too wet normally I just apply the
wash and walk away while it dries but in this instance I wanted to remove some of
it from the higher flat surfaces of the stucco so that it didn't look quite as
dark and grimy all over for this I just used some damp toilet paper to dab and
wipe away the excess from areas I wanted to remain lighter to make this process
easier I did one side of the building at a time so that I could wipe away the
wash while it was still wet if you wait until it dries you will need to use a
lot more water and abrasion to get the wash off areas and you're likely to wipe
off some of the paint below it in the process to add even more variety to the
paint job I next went in with a brown wash again this is just my homemade
recipe I hit a lot of the corners of the stucco and areas where I thought dirt
and crime was likely to settle I also wanted to add some mildew and organic
streaking to the piece so I mixed up a quick green wash to do this I just took
some very bright green acrylic ink and darkened it using my already made brown
wash this created a nice dark olive green wash that
could apply to areas where I wanted it to look like Moss and mildew were
forming on the building I focused mostly on the lower portion of the building
adding more to the corners and crevices but I also wanted a fair amount on the
wood shingles I tried to do this more in a streaking pattern with it focused
mostly on the drip edge of the roof to take this moss and mildew look even
further I created a three-dimensional moss
texture that I could apply this is really easy to do I simply take some
fine turf in a dark olive color and mix it with some watered-down PVA glue this
creates a sort of slurry that I can then brush on to the piece as the glue dries
it will go invisible leaving only the clumps of flocking this creates an
amazing look that is very durable on this build I made sure to only apply the
Moss to one side of the building so that all of the YouTube scientists didn't
have to scream in outrage in the comment section about moss only growing on one
side of things this one's for you now this is where I started to get
experimental right at the end of a basically finished piece which seems to
be a habit of mine I wanted to add glass to my windows this was especially
important because the order in which I built the house meant I was left with a
parchment paper behind the upper floor window and I wanted that to visually
disappear I decided to try using Vallejo water texture to create glass since I
wanted to hide the white parchment I didn't want this to dry completely clear
so I decided to tint it with a tiny bit of yellowy kind of orange paint in the
hopes of simulating glass lit by candlelight this was a little tricky to
apply from the mixing palette but I found I was able to do so with a brush
this water texture takes a while to cure so I left it for like over a day before
moving on to the next side for the lower windows I still needed something to hold
the water in place as it cured so I taped on some parchment to the inside of
the building to create sort of a I wanted to test how this stuff would
look if I just left it clear without any tinting so I was able to apply it this
time straight out of the bottle which was a lot easier than doing so with a
brush after it cured I was able to remove the parchment from the interior
and was left with just the clear water effects which created a pretty great
looking glass what's interesting is that even though I didn't tint the lower
windows they still ended up pretty yellow I've used this water texture in
other applications before and it dries totally clear
so I'm guessing what happened is that it hydrated and picked up some of the paint
or the wash from the piece and yellowed the resin this was fine by me it looked
pretty cool and old-world glass was never really that clear anyway one thing
I didn't like though was how it made the window frames very glossy which didn't
quite look right for a wood framed window to counteract as I went in with
some brush on matte varnish and painted out the wood frames
lastly I figured I'd put the glass windows to good use and add some
lighting effects you don't need to get too complicated with this you can just
use dollar store tea lights usually I don't even attach these to the piece so
that I can just swap them in and out easily but I decided to attach the one
for the upper floor to do this I just cut a tiny hole for the LED to go
through and hot glued the tea light to the ceiling of the piece the lower floor
I could just use freestanding tea lights overall I'm really happy with the way
this piece turned out I think the build is quite good and I'm really really
happy with the paint job and all the little finishing details if you want to
pick up any tools or supplies to tackle your own build head over to Blackmagic
crafts CA there I have my essential equipment store with links to all of the
stuff that I regularly use and recommend this way you get the tried and tested
tools and supplies and you can help fund videos like this one by shopping through
those Amazon affiliate links if you enjoy videos like this and you get a lot
of value out of them consider supporting Blackmagic crafts on patreon doing so
enables me to dedicate my time and efforts into making these
and helping out the community I'd love to have your support and mostly I'd love
to have you as the newest member of the black magic crafts fellowship there you
have it guys another build complete I'm really glad to see this one done and I'm
really happy with the way it turned out this is one I'm definitely proud to have
sitting on my shelves and I look forward to using it in some games it'll get some
limited use in D&D but it will have a lot of reusability in skirmish games
like Frost great I hope that you found this video and this entire series
enjoyable informative entertaining most of all inspiring if this series has
inspired you to build your own little Tudor style foam house I'd love to see
it so if you post pictures in places like the tabletop crafters guild
Facebook group or on Instagram be sure to tag black magic crafts so that I can
see it that's it for this week guys hope you have a great weekend
hopefully you play some games Cheers see you next week
